conbody.p: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture (DITA) is an XML-based architecture for creating, producing, and delivering content that is organized by topics and can be reused and shared in different ways. Although DITA has been primarily used for large-scale technical documentation, it is a standard that can be applied to any type of publication or information presented to readers. This includes interactive training and educational materials, standards, reports, business documents, trade books, travel and nature guides, and more.

Specialization enables the creation of specific, targeted XML grammars that can still use tools and design rules that were developed for more general types and domains; this is similar to how classes in an object-oriented system can inherit the methods of ancestor classes.
Because topics are conforming XML documents, they can be readily viewed, edited, and validated using standard XML tools, although realizing the full potential of requires using -aware tools.
